problem.p: You are a policeman investigating a car crash. Car #1 crashed into a stationary car #2. There is no indication that the driver of car #1 applied the brakes before the collision. After the collision, the two cars stuck together and slid until they came to rest.
Your goal is to determine whether car #1 was speeding before the collision. Consider the following steps for determining the speed of car #1.

ol.li: Measure the length (d) of the skid marks for the cars to determine how far they slid after the crash.
Look up the coefficient of kinetic friction ( \( \mu \) ) between the car tires and the ground.
Look up the masses of the two cars (m1, m2).
Find the amount of work done by friction as the cars slide, using the definition of work: \( Work = \int{\vec{F} \cdot d\vec{x}} = -\mu \left( m_1 + m_2 \right) g d \).
Use conservation of energy to determine the speed of the cars just after the crash, \(v_f\), via the equation \( \frac{1}{2} ( m_1 + m_2) v_f^2 = \mu ( m_1 + m_2 ) g d \).
Use conservation of energy to determine the initial velocity of the first car, \(v_1\), via the equation \( \frac{1}{2} m_1 v_1^2 = \frac{1}{2} (m_1 + m_2) v_f^2 \).
Compare \(v_1\) to the speed limit to see whether the car was speeding.

How do you know that the error is there?
